content: “monopolizing” the CF, and z/OS will be informed of this monopolization. New support in z/OS will observe the monopolization state for a structure, and start to selectively queue and throttle incoming requests to the CF, on a structure-specific basis – while other requests, for other “non-monopolizing” structures and workloads, are completely unaffected. z/OS will dynamically manage the queue of requests for the “monopolizing” structures to limit the number of active CF requests (parallelism) to them, and will monitor the CF’s monopolization state information so as to observe the structure becoming “non-monopolized” again, so that request processing can eventually revert back to a non-throttled mode of operation. The overall goal of z/OS anti-monopolization support is to protect the ability of ALL well-behaved structures and workloads to access the CF, and get their requests processed in the CF in a timely fashion – while implementing queueing and throttling mechanisms in z/OS to hold
